security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing only educational content about memory orchestration concepts. No executable code, no file access, no network calls, no environment access, and no command execution capabilities.

content.user_title: Analyze context memory systems in agent frameworks
content.value_statement: Agent frameworks struggle with context overflow and memory management. This skill provides systematic analysis of context assembly, eviction policies, and token budgeting strategies across different implementations.
actual_capabilities: Trace how prompts are assembled from system prompts, context, tools, history, and user input
Identify and evaluate eviction policies (FIFO, sliding window, summarization, vector store swapping)
Map memory tiers from working memory to persistent database storage
Analyze token counting strategies and budget allocation approaches
limitations: Does not modify or execute code in target frameworks
Requires codebase-mapping skill to identify memory-related files first
Cannot access live running systems or their memory states

faq.question: Which AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Each tool has different context window limits that affect memory strategy analysis.

faq.question: What are the context window limits?
faq.answer: Context limits vary by model. Claude Code supports up to 200K tokens. Smaller windows require more aggressive eviction policies.

faq.question: How does this integrate with other skills?
faq.answer: Run codebase-mapping first to find memory files. Feed findings into comparative-matrix for strategy comparisons. Combine with control-loop-extraction for scratchpad analysis.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only reads and analyzes code locally. No data is sent externally or persisted beyond the analysis session.

faq.question: Why does memory management matter?
faq.answer: Poor memory handling causes context loss, repeated instructions, and degraded performance in long conversations. Understanding patterns helps build more capable agents.

faq.question: How is this different from RAG?
faq.answer: RAG retrieves external documents. Memory orchestration manages conversation context and state continuity within the agent's processing loop.
